title: 1  Reference
text:
Note



Think of GitHub as a manual snapshot-oriented version of a cloud storage service (e.g. Box/Dropbox) that has been designed around collaborative coding.



Working directory

This is a folder on your local file system. It contains the files that you interact with (i.e. edit, read, and run).

Git

A distributed version control system, designed to handle collaborative coding projects. A program that is installed on your computer.

GitHub

A cloud-based hosting service that lets you manage Git repositories.

Commit

A snapshot of the files at one particular point in time.

Repo/Repository

A list of commits. Multiple files and their revision history. A top-level directory that has files monitored by Git is syncronized to GitHub. This directory is access controlled.

Local repo

The list of commits on your computer. You can make changes to files, commit them, and then add these commits to your local repo.

Remote repo

The centralized repository. Access controlled.

Branch

A parallel version of a repository. “main” is generally the default branch.

Pull

Fetch new commits from the remote repo and apply/merge them to your local repo.

Push

Send your commits to the remote repo.

SSH Key

A replacement for a username/password combination, in authenticating you to a server.

title: 2  Git Concepts
text:
2.1 Why Git/GitHub?
GitHub repos are used to store the code/scripts for projects.
Why do we want to use GitHub instead of a traditional cloud storage service? Because it is specifically designed for collaborative coding. In more concrete terms, this means:

It allows us to easily collaborate on code together.

Traditional cloud storage services push all changes instantaneously. This has a tendency to break code.

Conflicts are handled in a well-defined manner that makes sense for code.

Traditional cloud storage services do not handle this as well — they just save both files side-by-side.

It allows for the retrieval of earlier versions of code.
Can easily check how each file/line of code has developed over time.

Traditional cloud storage services have limited versioning options.

It provides a secure remote storage space for the code, in case of laptop theft/damage.

Same as traditional cloud storage services.

Access rights can be centrally controlled on a per-project basis.

If working within a GitHub organization, then access rights should be given via teams.

title: 2  Git Concepts
text:
2.2 Clone
The clone command is used to create a copy of a remote GitHub repo on your local computer (i.e. the initialization of the link between local and remote). This only has to happen once per repo/computer.
git clone git@github.com:csids/org.git

title: 2  Git Concepts
text:
2.3 Working directory
This is a folder on your local file system. It contains the files that you interact with (i.e. edit, read, and run).

title: 2  Git Concepts
text:
2.4 Commit
A commit is a saved snapshot of your repo at one particular point in time. You may choose to do this when you would like to either update the remote GitHub repo with your local code, or when you would like to sync your local code with updates from the remote GitHub repo.






Note



Remember that you can only commit files that have been staged (i.e. via the git add command)


git commit -m "Commit message"

2.8 Branches
Branches allow for multiple versions of your repo to exist simultaneously. For our purposes, we will ignore them, with the knowledge that everything we do will be on the ‘main’ branch.
